sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of travel outcome occurring on a trip
message_1: A cyclist wants to go on a bike trip but has to cancel 10% of the time due to weather conditions. If they plan 20 trips, what is the probability that at least 15 of them will happen?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (trips happening) in n trials (planned trips)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (n! / (k!(n-k)!))
- p is the probability of success (trip happening) = 1 - probability of cancellation = 1 - 0.1 = 0.9
- n is the number of trials (planned trips) = 20
- k is the number of successes (trips happening)

We want to find the probability that at least 15 trips will happen, which means we need to find the probability for 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, and 20 successful trips and add them together.

P(X ≥ 15) = P(X = 15) + P(X = 16) + P(X = 17) + P(X = 18) + P(X = 19) + P(X = 20)

We can calculate each probability using the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 15) = C(20, 15) * 0.9^15 * 0.1^5
P(X = 16) = C(20, 16) * 0.9^16 * 0.1^4
P(X = 17) = C(20, 17) * 0.9^17 * 0.1^3
P(X = 18) = C(20, 18) * 0.9^18 * 0.1^2
P(X = 19) = C(20, 19) * 0.9^19 * 0.1^1
P(X = 20) = C(20, 20) * 0.9^20 * 0.1^0

Now, we can calculate the probabilities:

P(X = 15) ≈ 0.0319
P(X = 16) ≈ 0.0574
P(X = 17) ≈ 0.0573
P(X = 18) ≈ 0.0383
P(X = 19) ≈ 0.0139
P(X = 20) ≈ 0.0021

Finally, we add the probabilities together:

P(X ≥ 15) ≈ 0.0319 + 0.0574 + 0.0573 + 0.0383 + 0.0139 + 0.0021 ≈ 0.2009

So, the probability that at least 15 trips will happen is approximately 20.09%.
